name: 2014_05_humanities_student_major_622_cscareerquestions
title: 2014-05-humanities-student-major_622_cscareerquestions.txt
content_scrubbed:
I would work towards a degree, but apply for junior developer roles the second you start school. Alternatively, since you're a year out of school and have been presumably financing yourself without loans, self-paced learning. 

It[.] been my experience that most smaller and mid-size companies who are looking for a junior dev like a degree, but like proactive learning more. If you can actually show code that you've posted up on Github, you'd be ahead of most CS graduates I know. There are plenty of resources already for hands on, open source education, but I'd like to recommend Udacity and Coursera. Of the courses I've taken, I would point you towards Udacity[.] Intro Programming and Web Development courses (both Python).

Take it with a grain of salt, but your experience was pretty close to mine a couple of years ago. Double majored in liberal_arts. Applied for a QA position while entertaining law school acceptance letters. Interviewed well and they offered me a dev spot. It was still a toss up, because I had felt so committed to law school. My starting salary ended up being more than I was hoping for after law school. FWIW, I wouldn't trade my degrees and they have made me a much better learner and critical thinker (yes, I'm aware of how cheesy that sounds).

I realize this is all very anecdotal, but if you'd like some more specifics, feel free to PM me. I'd love to be of help.

TL;DR Almost pulled the trigger on law school. I write software for lawyers now and always seem happier than they do.
